channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: How China Has Added to Its Influence Over the iPhone
item.description: Apple is taking small steps toward India. But the production of its latest phone, set for introduction on Wednesday, shows how difficult it will be to make big changes.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:description: Chinese engineers are playing a greater role in the creation of iPhones, even as Apple takes baby steps toward production outside the country.

item.title: Tech Companies Slowly Shift Production Away From China
item.description: Worried about geopolitical tensions and stung by pandemic shutdowns, Google, Apple and others are moving some work to nearby countries.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Quang Chau Industrial Park, which includes Foxconn factories, in Bac Giang Province, Vietnam.

item.title: Juul Settles Multistate Youth Vaping Inquiry for $438.5 Million
item.description: The tentative deal would close an investigation by nearly three dozen states into the company’s marketing and sales practices.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: An investigation found that the company had a “porous” age verification system for its products and that 45 percent of its Twitter followers were ages 13 to 17.

item.title: Bannon to Surrender to New York Authorities to Face Sealed Indictment
item.description: After President Donald J. Trump pardoned him in a case connected to a crowd-funded border wall, the Manhattan district attorney’s office opened its own investigation.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Lexey Swall for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon, pardoned by former President Donald Trump in 2021, is turning himself in.

item.title: Judge Unseats Official Who Trespassed at Capitol on Jan. 6
item.description: The ruling made Couy Griffin, a county commissioner in New Mexico, the first official in more than 100 years to be removed under the Constitution’s bar on insurrectionists holding office.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
item.category: Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington
item.media:credit: Matt Dahlseid/Santa Fe New Mexican, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Couy Griffin, an Otero County commissioner, responded to questioning in court, after watching a video of himself on U.S. Capitol grounds on Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: Video Raises Concerns About Election Data Breach in Georgia County
item.description: Surveillance video from rural Coffee County, Ga., raised new questions about the extent to which election data was improperly shared with pro-Trump figures challenging the 2020 election results.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Sean Keenan
item.media:description: In footage from Jan. 7, 2021, obtained by The Times, Cathy Latham, bottom, at the time the chair of the Coffee County Republican Party, welcomes a team of SullivanStrickler data scientists.

item.title: Special Masters and the Trump Records Investigation, Explained
item.description: An independent arbiter’s review of government documents seized at the former president’s home could significantly delay the criminal inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Florida judge emphasized Donald J. Trump’s status as a former president in granting his request for a special master.

item.title: Former Pentagon Leaders Warn of a Dangerous Era
item.description: The challenge to the 2020 election result has helped create “an extremely adverse environment,” former defense secretaries and generals said in an open letter.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: In summer 2020, General Mark A. Milley, right, was summoned by President Donald J. Trump for a walk across a park where protesters had just been tear-gassed so Mr. Trump could do a photo op holding a Bible.

item.title: Canada Stabbing Suspect Remains at Large After Manhunt in Saskatchewan
item.description: The police received reports that Myles Sanderson was spotted at the Indigenous reserve where the stabbings took place, but by day’s end he was not in custody, and an emergency alert was still in place for Saskatchewan.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen, Vjosa Isai and Yonette Joseph
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police vehicle at James Smith Cree Nation after a report that Myles Sanderson may have been spotted there.

item.title: Seattle Storm’s Sue Bird Ends WNBA Career With Playoff Loss
item.description: Bird, 41, the Seattle Storm guard, had said she would retire after this season. The Storm fell to the Las Vegas Aces in the W.N.B.A. semifinals on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Shauntel Lowe
item.media:description: Seattle Storm guard Sue Bird is retiring from the W.N.B.A. after 21 years. She became emotional as her home crowd cheered for her after the Storm lost to the Aces on Tuesday.

item.title: Christine Baranski Brings Throwback Flair to Her Ripped-From-the-Headlines Stardom
item.description: The actress is back for the final season of “The Good Fight.”
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Camila Falquez for The New York Times

item.title: The World Is Getting Less Flat
item.description: Why (some) manufacturing is coming home.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman

item.title: With Malice Toward Quite a Few
item.description: When it comes to saving democracy, Joe Biden slumps to the occasion.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens

item.title: Lea Michele, ’Funny Girl’ and the Question of Second Chances
item.description: What happens when a canceled star makes a comeback?
item.dc:creator: Jessica Bennett
item.media:credit: Gioncarlo Valentine for The New York Times

item.title: Debtors, Unite! You Have Nothing to Lose but Your Shame.
item.description: Conversations about debt are never purely about economics. They are always also conversations about power and morality.
item.dc:creator: Astra Taylor

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Wasting Time and Money
item.description: I have deep doubts about the intellectual and social value of schooling.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Caplan
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; Warren K. Leffler, via Library of Congress; photos-public-domain.com; and Charles Deluvio and Subhash Nusetti, via Unsplash

item.title: Liz Truss, Britain’s New Prime Minister, Is Still in Thrall to the Empire
item.description: Liz Truss is absorbed in imperial thinking.
item.dc:creator: Kojo Koram
item.media:description: Liz Truss, Britain’s incoming prime minister.

item.title: The Subtle Art of Appreciating ‘Difficult Beauty’
item.description: The writer Chloé Cooper Jones talks about bodies, disability and how searching for beauty can change our lives.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: Chile’s Constitutional Fight Over Climate Change
item.description: Chileans rejected a proposed constitution that would have been the first to confront climate change. But they are not done.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:description: Chileans voted to reject a new constitution on Sunday.

item.title: The Run-Up: The Stakes of the 2022 Midterm Elections
item.description: This November, Americans will head to the polls for the first major political test since Jan. 6.
item.media:credit: Photo illustration: The New York Times; Photo: Samuel Corum for The New York Times

item.title: Apple, the Ad Critic, Now Embraces Ads
item.description: Apple has long supported privacy and shunned those intrusive ads. What happens when it sells more ads, too?
item.dc:creator: Shira Ovide

item.title: Are You in a Moral Quandary?
item.description: We’d like to discuss it with you, live on Twitter Spaces, with the magazine’s Ethicist columnist, Kwame Anthony Appiah. Let us know below what’s troubling you.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: A News Anchor Had Stroke Symptoms on Air. Her Colleagues Jumped Into Action.
item.description: Julie Chin, an anchor with the Tulsa, Okla., NBC affiliate KJRH, thanked her colleagues for helping her get medical attention immediately and said she was recovering.
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Julie Chin, a KJRH news anchor.

item.title: Liz Truss Takes Over as Prime Minister, Promising Britons They Can ‘Ride Out the Storm’
item.description: Liz Truss takes over as prime minister at a time of deepening economic crisis. Her first cabinet appointments reward loyalists who supported her bid for office.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Britain’s new prime minister, Liz Truss, with her husband, Hugh O’Leary, after giving her first speech, at Downing Street on Tuesday.

item.title: Contractor at Center of Navy Bribery Scandal Flees House Arrest
item.description: Leonard Glenn Francis, who is known as Fat Leonard, was less than three weeks away from his sentencing date when he cut off his GPS anklet and left his home in San Diego, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A ‘Period Dignity Officer’ Seemed Like a Good Idea. Until a Man Was Named.
item.description: The job in the Scottish region of Tayside was eliminated after a groundswell of anger that a man would be overseeing, or ‘mansplaining,’ menstruation policy.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The Scottish Parliament. Scotland was the first country to adopt a law requiring universal free access to period products.

item.title: Can You Get Addicted to Melatonin?
item.description: The sleep supplement doesn’t cause physical dependence, but falling asleep without it can be tricky for some people.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: How to Sleep During a Heat Wave
item.description: While it may be difficult to drift off when temperatures rise, there are things you can do to snooze more soundly.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman and Nicole Stock

item.title: Night Sweats Causes: Experts Explain Why You Sweat In Your Sleep
item.description: There are many possible reasons you might wake up in a pool of perspiration. Here’s how to tell when it should be cause for concern.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Wide Awake at 3 A.M.? Readers Offer Advice on Insomnia
item.description: Well readers share a range of strategies they use to get back to sleep in the middle of the night.
item.dc:creator: Anahad O’Connor

item.title: Javier Zamora Carried a Heavy Load. He Laid It to Rest on the Page.
item.description: Decades after traveling without his parents from El Salvador to the U.S. as a 9-year-old — a journey that almost killed him — Zamora describes the experience in a memoir.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin P. Russell
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I don’t expect the people who are in the book to read it. But my dream scenario is that they open it,” Zamora said, “and see that there is this book out there thanking them.”
